info.title: Permit.io PDP
info.description: The PDP (Policy decision point) container wraps Open Policy Agent (OPA) with a higher-level API intended for fine grained application-level authorization. The PDP automatically handles pulling policy updates in real-time from a centrally managed cloud-service (api.permit.io).

get.description: List all the callbacks currently registered by OPAL client.

post.description:
Register a new callback by OPAL client, to be called on OPA state
updates.

get.description:
Get a callback by its key (if such callback is indeed
registered).

delete.description:
Unregisters a callback identified by its key (if such callback is
indeed registered).

schema.title: Response Get User Permissions User Permissions Post
Response Get User Tenants User Tenants Post

get.description:
Get all role assignments stored in the PDP.

You can filter the results by providing optional filters.

parameters.description: optional user filter, will only return role assignments granted to this user.

schema.title: User
schema.description: optional user filter, will only return role assignments granted to this user.

parameters.name: user

parameters.description: optional role filter, will only return role assignments granting this role.

schema.title: Role
schema.description: optional role filter, will only return role assignments granting this role.

parameters.name: role

parameters.description: optional tenant filter, will only return role assignments granted in that tenant.

schema.title: Tenant
schema.description: optional tenant filter, will only return role assignments granted in that tenant.

parameters.name: tenant

parameters.description: optional resource **type** filter, will only return role assignments granted on that resource type.

schema.title: Resource
schema.description: optional resource **type** filter, will only return role assignments granted on that resource type.

parameters.name: resource

parameters.description: optional resource instance filter, will only return role assignments granted on that resource instance.

schema.title: Resource Instance
schema.description: optional resource instance filter, will only return role assignments granted on that resource instance.

parameters.name: resource_instance

parameters.description: Page number of the results to fetch, starting at 1.

schema.title: Page
schema.description: Page number of the results to fetch, starting at 1.

parameters.name: page

parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

schema.title: Per Page
schema.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

parameters.name: per_page

tenant.title: Tenant
tenant.description: The tenant that the user is authorized for

resource.title: Resource
resource.description: The resource that the user is authorized for

role.title: Role
role.description: The role that the user is assigned to

resource.title: Resource
resource.description: The resource that the result is about.Can be either 'resource:*' or 'resource:resource_instance'

tenant.title: Tenant
tenant.description: The tenant that the result is about

users.title: Users
users.description: A key value mapping of the users that are authorized for the resource.The key is the user key and the value is a list of assignments allowing the user to performthe requested action

key.title: Key
key.description: unique id to identify this callback (optional)

url.title: Url
url.description: http/https url to call back on update

config.title: Config
config.description: optional http config for the target url (i.e: http method, headers, etc)

CallbackEntry.title: CallbackEntry
CallbackEntry.description:
An entry in the callbacks register.

this schema is used by the callbacks api

fetcher.title: Fetcher
fetcher.description: indicates to OPAL client that it should use a custom FetcherProvider to fetch the data

HttpFetcherConfig.title: HttpFetcherConfig
HttpFetcherConfig.description: Config for HttpFetchProvider's Adding HTTP headers.

type.description: the type of policy store, currently only OPA is officially supported

url.title: Url
url.description: the url that OPA can be found in. if localhost is the host - it means OPA is on the same hostname as OPAL client.

token.title: Token
token.description: optional access token required by the policy store

auth_type.description: the type of authentication is supported for the policy store.

oauth_client_id.title: Oauth Client Id
oauth_client_id.description: optional OAuth client id required by the policy store

oauth_client_secret.title: Oauth Client Secret
oauth_client_secret.description: optional OAuth client secret required by the policy store

oauth_server.title: Oauth Server
oauth_server.description: optional OAuth server required by the policy store

PolicyStoreDetails.title: PolicyStoreDetails
PolicyStoreDetails.description:
represents a policy store endpoint - contains the policy store's:
- location (url)
- type
- credentials

user.title: User
user.description: the user the role is assigned to

tenant.title: Tenant
tenant.description: the tenant the role is associated with

resource_instance.title: Resource Instance
resource_instance.description: the resource instance the role is associated with

RoleAssignment.title: RoleAssignment
RoleAssignment.description: The format of a role assignment

tags.name: Authorization API
tags.description: Authorization queries to OPA. These queries are answered locally by OPA and do not require the cloud service. Latency should be very low (< 20ms per query)

tags.name: Local Queries
tags.description: These queries are done locally against the sidecar and do not involve a network round-trip to Permit.io cloud API. Therefore they are safe to use with reasonable performance (i.e: with negligible latency) in the context of a user request.

tags.name: Policy Updater
tags.description: API to manually trigger and control the local policy caching and refetching.

tags.name: Cloud API Proxy
tags.description: These endpoints proxy the Permit.io cloud api, and therefore **incur high-latency**. You should not use the cloud API in the standard request flow of users, i.e in places where the incurred added latency will affect your entire api. A good place to call the cloud API will be in one-time user events such as user registration (i.e: calling sync user, assigning initial user roles, etc.). The sidecar will proxy to the cloud every request prefixed with '/sdk'.
